title: In Wonder Man Yahya Abdul-Mateen II Perfectly Captures The Anxiety Of Excellence
text:
In Wonder Man Yahya Abdul-Mateen II Perfectly Captures The Anxiety Of Excellence

Mere minutes into Wonder Man, I had to take a break from the series. Not because it wasnâ€™t good â€” itâ€™s great â€” but because I saw so much of myself in Simon Williams and his relentless anxiety, it was, well, making me anxious. Lately, it feels like conversations surrounding representation and have been flattened, and we decide if a piece of art is good only if we can see ourselves in it. I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s true. And I think Wonder Man is a brilliant show, whether youâ€™re a self-flagulating overthinker like Simon and me or not, but when I was watching it, I was struck by how real he felt, and how rarely we get to see anxious Black characters, especially Black men, onscreen.Â 

All eight episodes of Wonder Man drop on Disney+ today and in the Marvel series, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II stars as Simon, a struggling actor who just wants to be seen for his craft, not the anger-induced superpowers heâ€™s desperately trying to hide and has no idea what to do with. You may think youâ€™re getting an origin story for one of Marvelâ€™s most underrated superheroes, but as its eight episodes unfold, Wonder Man quietly transforms into one of the most honest portrayals of anxiety Iâ€™ve seen in a superhero show, maybe in any show. Simonâ€™s overthinking, his paralysis in the face of opportunity, his fear that one misstep will cost him everything hit so close to home. Created by Destin Daniel Cretton (â€œShang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Ringsâ€) and Andrew Guest (who has written for â€œCommunityâ€ and â€œBrooklyn Nine-Nineâ€), Wonder Man is a slow burn meditation on Hollywood, ambition, and who gets to be a hero. And after all these years of oversaturation accusations and critiques that superhero projects have nothing more to offer, this is the MCU at its best and most original.Â Â 

Thereâ€™s this scene early in the series where Simon shows up to set for a small role on American Horror Story. Heâ€™s done his research, prepared a whole backstory, and workshopped different line deliveries. Heâ€™s in his head. When he starts suggesting tweaks to the scene, the director humors him at first, then grows frustrated, and finally, he gets fired on the spot. Watching Simonâ€™s face collapse as he realizes heâ€™s sabotaged himself yet again â€” that he tried so hard to be excellent that he forgot to just be â€” is what made me pause the episode. I had to sit with it for a minute because Iâ€™ve been that person, the one so terrified of mediocrity that I self sabotage, the one who shows up with five times the preparation and still feels like an imposter. But Simon isnâ€™t shy or lacking confidence necessarily, heâ€™s anxious because he wants to be the best. Heâ€™s anxious because he feels like he knows the character better than anyone, even the director. Itâ€™s bravado and fear warring with and wrapped up in each other, and itâ€™s a dangerous combination.Â 

â€œAnxiety is kind of new to me too. I understand what itâ€™s like,â€ Abdul Mateen II says, sitting across from me during the filmâ€™s junket in Los Angeles. â€œAs an actor, a part of our job is to be able to identify the anxieties and to be able to use our tools to decrease it and then to work through it, to â€˜tolerate our discomfort.â€™â€Â 

And it is uncomfortable at times to watch Simon war with his own mind, struggling through who he knows he can be and who he is. Abdul-Mateen II brings so much depth and sensitivity to Simonâ€™s anxiety. This isnâ€™t the one-note brooding, mysterious kind of troubled hero weâ€™re used to seeing. Simonâ€™s anxiety is mundane, messy, and for Abdul-Mateen II, it was personal.Â 

â€œIt was really gratifying, and sometimes scary at the same time, to show that vulnerability, to show that anxiety, to show what it looks like to just not be sure of myself at all but still have to proceed, and to have the camera be right here while Iâ€™m doing that,â€ He says, gesturing with his hand close to his face. â€œTo be feeling something before a scene and to realize, â€˜Oh, yeah thatâ€™s right, this is what Simon is feelingâ€™. Oh, OK so Iâ€™m right at home so just share it. Iâ€™m just there to share it.â€

What Abdul-Mateen II shares is revelatory. Itâ€™s one of the strongest performances the MCU has ever seen. And at times when the script doesnâ€™t give us much about Simonâ€™s interior, Abdul-Mateen II fills in the rest of the story with his face. Simonâ€™s anxiety shows up in him standing outside an audition rehearsing the same line forty-seven different ways, or calling his ex-girlfriend to apologize for apologizing too much, or him lying awake at 3 a.m. mentally cataloging every interaction he had that day, searching for where he went wrong. Thereâ€™s a scene where Simon practices his audition in front of a bathroom mirror, and you can see him cycling through emotions â€” confidence, doubt, overcompensation, resignation â€” in the span of thirty seconds. Itâ€™s exhausting and exhilarating to watch Abdul-Mateen II work. Itâ€™s also deeply, painfully relatable.Â 

Wonder Man connects Simonâ€™s anxiety to his Blackness without making it the sole defining factor. Simon doesnâ€™t just want to be a good actor; he wants to prove he belongs in spaces that werenâ€™t built for him. Thereâ€™s this unspoken weight he carries, this understanding that his margin for error is razor-thin. One mistake and heâ€™s not just Simon Williams who messed up; heâ€™s a confirmation of every stereotype and every lowered expectation. Itâ€™s the burden of representation that so many Black creatives carry, the exhausting math of needing to be twice as excellent to be considered half as good. Itâ€™s such a prevailing understanding, itâ€™s become a clichÃ©. And so the show doesnâ€™t need to spell this out in obvious dialogue, which I appreciate. Instead, it lives in Abdul-Mateenâ€™s performance, the way Simonâ€™s shoulders tense when he walks into a dinner full of white executives (save for his agent Janelle, played pitch perfectly by X Mayo) trying to push him to capitalize on his Wonder Man casting, the way he code-switches without even realizing heâ€™s doing it, the way he shrinks around his overachieving brother and how the legacy of his late father is simmering beneath every decision Simon makes.Â 

The genius of the series is pairing Simon with Sir Ben Kingsleyâ€™s Trevor Slattery, a washed-up actor (also known as The Mandarin, making his fourth MCU appearance) whoâ€™s decided that â€œgood enoughâ€ is, in fact, good enough. Trevor is delightfully shameless in his mediocrity. He shows up to auditions unprepared and somehow charms his way through. He forgets his lines and improvises. He lives in the moment because heâ€™s already survived the worst his career can throw at him. Heâ€™s also acting as a double agent, spying on Simon for the governmentâ€™s Department of Damage Control. Agent Cleary (Successionâ€™s Arian Moayed) is his point person at the bureau tasked with bringing in â€œenhancedâ€ individuals. This part of the script is its weakest, because itâ€™s never really clear why Simon is a target when heâ€™s hiding his powers and can barely control them, but the beauty of Wonder Man is that it doesnâ€™t care much about the MCU politics of it all. This is a small story an unlikely friendship forged between two actors who approach life differently â€“ one living like heâ€™s got nothing to lose (Trevor) and the other carefully clinging to things he doesnâ€™t have yet.Â 

Their dynamic is hilarious. Simonâ€™s anxious perfectionism is constantly butting up against Trevorâ€™s chaotic â€œweâ€™ll figure it outâ€ energy and itâ€™s also the emotional heart of the show. Trevor becomes the person who gives Simon permission to be imperfect, to make mistakes, to take up space without apology. Their friendship is a quiet rebellion. And when you juxtapose the purity of Simon and Trevorâ€™s bond with what goes on between Byron Bowersâ€™ DeMarr â€œDoormanâ€ Davis and Josh Gad (playing the asshole version of himself) in Episode 4 (a truly revolutionary, gorgeous, gutting episode), itâ€™s even more evident how special their friendship is.Â 

My favorite scene of the series comes when Simon and Trevor are at the house of the famed eccentric director or Wonder Man (the movie within the show) participating in a day-long audition. When put on the spot to improvise a monologue, Simon cracks and resorts to reciting a scene from Pretty Woman. Yes, that Pretty Woman. Abdul Mateen II says he had fun channeling his inner Julia Roberts, but aside from the comedy of that scene, itâ€™s more proof of Simonâ€™s debilitating anxiety.Â 

â€œThat just shows how much of a wreck Simon is. Simon is a control freak. He has a photographic memory so he remembers every line from every movie heâ€™s ever seen. He has it in his head. That was a lot of fun. Heâ€™s trying his best,â€ Abdul Mateen II says with a laugh.Â 

I keep thinking about what Abdul-Mateen said in a recent interview with Esquire, how Simon â€œlives his life always trying to avoid the next worst thingâ€ and that â€œitâ€™s paralyzing.â€ That line stayed with me because it perfectly describes what so many of us are navigating, this constant vigilance, this bracing for impact, this belief that if we just work hard enough, prepare thoroughly enough, excel sufficiently enough, we can somehow protect ourselves from the unfairness we know is coming. But Simonâ€™s journey in Wonder Man is learning that excellence isnâ€™t armor. Sometimes itâ€™s the opposite. Sometimes our desperate need to be exceptional keeps us from actually living, from taking risks, from being human. The show doesnâ€™t offer easy answers (spoiler: Simon doesnâ€™t suddenly stop being anxious by the finale) but it does give him permission to be a work in progress. To be, dare I say it, mediocre sometimes. And that feels radical.

Wonder Man is technically a superhero show, but itâ€™s really about what happens when you realize that the superpowers youâ€™ve been hiding might be less scary than the ordinary vulnerabilities you refuse to show. The Marvel series is a surprisingly tender meditation on perfectionism, performance, and the paralyzing fear of not being enough. Itâ€™s about the courage it takes to just show up as yourself â€” flawed, uncertain, still figuring it out â€” in a world that demands perfection from people who look like you. Abdul-Mateenâ€™s performance is quietly devastating in its specificity, and the series as a whole is a love letter to everyone whoâ€™s ever felt like theyâ€™re one mistake away from losing everything. Itâ€™s a reminder that sometimes the most revolutionary thing we can do is give ourselves permission to just be fine, not exceptional, not extraordinary, just fine. And, honestly, that might be the superpower we need most.

title: Kiernan Shipka Is All Grown Up And Ready To Redefine Herself With Industry
text:
Kiernan Shipka Is All Grown Up And Ready To Redefine Herself With Industry

In some ways, itâ€™s felt like weâ€™ve grown up alongside Kiernan Shipka. She had her first role as a baby on TV at just five months old on ER, before becoming Sally Draper in Mad Men in 2006. From there, she took on perfectly age-appropriate roles, voicing Jinora in Nickelodeonâ€™s The Legend of Korra, and as the title character in YA series Chilling Adventures of Sabrina. Over the past two years, sheâ€™s started branching out into more mature roles, in films such as Longlegs, Twisters and The Last Showgirl, but her latest turn as Haley in Industry Season 4 proves sheâ€™s well and truly shed her child-star image.

During Episode 3, Shipkaâ€™s character is seen having a threesome with Henry (Kit Harington) and his wife Yasmin (Marisa Abela), who happen to yield an immense amount of power over her. As is the case with Industry, itâ€™s a drawn-out sex scene, lingering much more than most TV shows dare. Shipka tells Refinery29 she didnâ€™t deliberately choose to be part of Industry for the sake of being seen as more grown up, but itâ€™s come about in a natural and intentional way. â€œIâ€™ve sort of taken my time [and] I think I was really itching to play something that was a bit more adult and a bit older, being that Iâ€™m 26 now. I was 25 when I shot the show, and I wanted to do something that was in that space and felt reflective of who I was [in terms of] the age,â€ Shipka says. â€œBut I think if I had done it earlier, it would have been me forcing it, and this just felt like a show that I wanted to be part of anyway, and it was also a plus that I got to show myself in sort of a different way than people are used to seeing me.â€

She acknowledges that itâ€™s a â€œtricky transitionâ€ when you start as a child star, but the actor hasnâ€™t been stressed about choosing the exact right career move. â€œIâ€™ve always wanted to prioritise patience over doing something impulsive that wasnâ€™t right. And I feel really lucky that I get to be part of great projects and pick fun things,â€ Shipka explains. â€œThereâ€™s pros and cons to starting that young, but I think thereâ€™s something inherently exciting about redefining yourself. And I find myself in that moment right now, and I find myself really excited by it.â€

Joining an established and loved series in a later season is tough for even the most seasoned pros, yet Shipka wasnâ€™t fazed by the high stakes. For the actor, she found the project excited her, and took value from each scene, including that sex scene in Episode 3. â€œThat [scene] honestly has so much going on outside of the sex itself, like itâ€™s a big emotional catalyst for all three characters in very vastly different ways. And I think thatâ€™s what I loved about the scene so much, was that it was kind of layered,â€ she recalls. â€œIt was a really enriching scene to shoot. I mean, it felt like it was an important scene.â€

The Industry creators have been vocal about how the show uses intimacy coordinators on set, especially seeing as the show has a high rate of nudity and sex throughout. Shipka says her sex scene with Harington and Abela was choreographed before the shoot day, so it didnâ€™t feel uncomfortable at all. â€œEverything was talked about beforehand, and we had an intimacy coordinator and really mapped out the scene so that on the day we could just focus on the characters and the scene itself,â€ she says. â€œEveryoneâ€™s a pro, so it was nice.â€ Abelaâ€™s character Yasmin has an unusual connection with Haley, so every scene they shot together (including this one) helped develop their bond. â€œ[Abela is] so magnetic, sheâ€™s so present. Itâ€™s so easy to act with her, because sheâ€™s so amazing. We had so much fun,â€ Shipka says. â€œI think thereâ€™s a really special bond between Haley and Yasmin that even sort of lifts off whatâ€™s scripted and is just sort of in the air. And so much of that is a testament to chemistry, and Marisa is just such a force that itâ€™s so easy to be captivated by her.â€

The star is unable to share any spoilers about how important her character Haley will be down the line, but hints that there could be a power shift. She seems to be at the bottom of the pecking order, with lines constantly being stepped over by her bosses (as expected, this isÂ Industry, after all), but even the most die-hard fans will be intrigued by whatâ€™s to come. â€œThis season [circulates] around this theme of power and how power can look so different for different people. And I think you have someone like Haley, who presents as someone who is not in a position of power at all, and yet she finds it, and she finds her power throughout this system.

â€œI think itâ€™s great to tell Haleyâ€™s version of that through her eyes, because itâ€™s a version, and to tell only one story of power isnâ€™t really the whole picture.â€

title: The Honest Truth About Rosemary Oil & Hair Growth
text:
The Honest Truth About Rosemary Oil & Hair Growth

FromÂ thickening shampoosÂ toÂ retinol (yes, retinol), the topic ofÂ hair growthÂ has been taking over TikTok for a while now, with countless solutions sitting under the hashtag. Rosemary oil is one of the buzziest topics in the lineup ofÂ viral ingredients, and TikTokers are dubbing it a one-way ticket toÂ growing your hairÂ naturally.

Racking up billions of views and counting, thereâ€™s a good reason why theÂ hashtag #rosemaryoilÂ is trending again: Like so many of the hyped up ingredients that came before it, a collective concern overÂ hair loss is fueling the demand. And whatâ€™s more appealing than a simple, natural remedy?

â€œBefore and aftersâ€ show impressiveÂ hair growthÂ results, but experts are warning that thereâ€™s more to the story. So isÂ rosemary oilÂ the silver bullet solution for hair growth, after all? Or is it a herb that could do your hair more harm than good?

Hereâ€™s what the experts think.

What is rosemary oil?Â 

â€œRosemary oil is the oil from the rosemary plant, also known as rosmarinus officinalis L.,â€ explainsÂ ZoÃ« Passam, consultant trichologist atÂ Philip Kingsley. For years, the herb has been used to treat a host of ailments, for aromatherapy, skincare formulas, and haircare.

â€œRosemary has a long tradition of use as an importantÂ essential oilÂ for a wide range of issues, most famously to improve memory and concentration, which goes back as far as ancient Greece,â€ adds Alison Pawlus, principal scientistÂ at Aveda.

Itâ€™sÂ â€œnaturalâ€, tooÂ â€” perhaps one reason why the ears of TikTokers have pricked up. â€œThereâ€™s growing interest in finding naturally derived solutions to help with hair growth, either to promoteÂ longer, healthier hairÂ or in individuals withÂ hair thinning,â€ explains Pawlus.Â

What are the benefits of rosemary oil for hair?Â 

Rosemary oil has a host of potential benefits. â€œIt contains compounds which have been shown to have some anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial and antioxidant activities,â€ explainsÂ Dr. Sharon Wong, consultant dermatologist and hair specialist. All such properties reduceÂ scalp irritation, while antioxidants specifically help protect your hair from external aggressors such as pollution. Put simply, this tends to equal stronger strands andÂ a healthier scalp.

â€œRosemary oil can help with nourishment and locking inÂ the hairâ€™s moisture,Â and it has properties that improveÂ blood circulation to the scalp, while getting rid of any bacteria that clog hair follicles,â€ addsÂ Hannah Gaboardi, leading trichologist and brand ambassadorÂ at Viviscal.

Is rosemary oil good for hair growth?

There has been some data that suggests rosemary oil could be good for hair growth, with two specific studies that point to its potential. â€œAÂ study in 2015Â compared the effects of rosemary oil versusÂ 2% minoxidilÂ [a topical medication] for the treatment ofÂ androgenetic alopeciaÂ [male and female pattern hair loss] and, after six months, found a similar increase in hair counts with both treatments,â€ says Passam. AnotherÂ study foundÂ that rosemary [essential] oil was an effective treatment for the patchy hair loss condition known asÂ alopecia areata.

Though promising, these studies are small, and the scientific researchis still preliminary. To add, the data is directed towards genetic hair loss (androgenetic alopecia) as opposed to analyzing specific types. Pawlus adds that rosemary oil has several beneficial compounds, but these studies speak exclusively of the essential oil, which is â€œthe volatile, aromatic component of plants [what you smell], which excludes some of rosemaryâ€™s powerful antioxidants.â€

The issue? TheÂ quality of the oilÂ can vary. â€œIt depends on many factors, including the growth conditions of the plant, the quality of the plant collected, and how it was handled prior to extraction,â€ says Pawlus.

Is it safe to use rosemary oil on your hair and scalp?

The experts say that, in theory, people withÂ all hair typesÂ can use rosemary oil, but some may want to proceed with caution. â€œAlthough natural, as with all plant extracts and botanicals, rosemary oil extracts and the raw material itself can potentially causeÂ skin irritationÂ and allergicÂ contact dermatitisÂ in some people,â€ explains Dr. Wong.

A possible catalyst for irritation is when using the oil alone. Despite what the TikTok videos might suggest, pure rosemary essential oil (andÂ essential oilsÂ in general) is very potent and could cause scalp irritation. Worse yet, it might have the opposite of the intended effect. â€œMaintaining aÂ healthy scalpÂ plays a fundamental role in supporting healthy hair growth by providing conditions to optimize the function of the hair follicle,â€ adds Dr. Wong. â€œThere are many examples in which an unhealthy scalp can lead to increased hair lossÂ such as eczema, psoriasis, fungal infections, orÂ yeast overgrowth.â€

To that end, if you are going to use rosemary oil, make sure youâ€™re diluting it with another oil-based product and massaging it into your scalp, says Gaboardi. â€œI recommend mixing four or five drops with a teaspoon of oil, likeÂ coconut oil. You can then massage it evenly into your scalp.â€ It is also said that the massaging action might be the catalyst for stimulating hair growth. â€œScalp massaging can helpÂ increase hair thicknessÂ by stretching the cells of hair follicles, which then stimulates the follicles to produce thicker hair,â€ says Gaboardi. Never apply rosemary oil to inflamed or broken skin, adds Passam.

How do you use rosemary oil for hair growth?Â 

Aside from diluting it, not all rosemary oil formulas are created equal. Though skeptical about using rosemary oil as a hair growth treatment altogether, Passam suggests itâ€™s best applied as a leave-in product so that it has a greater chance of exerting its effects. â€œI would always recommend using rosemary oil in conjunction with other products [suchÂ as shampoosÂ and serums] that support hair growth,â€ adds Gaboardi, who says aÂ balanced dietÂ andÂ supplementation are key.

Though plenty of new videos are surfacing to set the record straight, the misinformation thatâ€™s being bandied about on TikTok is exactly whatâ€™s causingÂ concern among experts. Lack of education aside, many donâ€™t look at the root of the problem. â€œAs a trichologist, my main concern would be that people may follow these trends when they would be better served finding out the reason for their hair loss and addressing this under the guidance of a specialist,â€ says Passam. â€œSome types of hair loss are progressive, so seeking appropriate advice early is likely to lead to better outcomes,â€ she adds.

This isnâ€™t to say that rosemary oil doesnâ€™t have a place in yourÂ haircare routine, but more research is needed to understand whether it can really promote hair growth and density. For now, quality control and education is your best bet to determine whether you might want to try it out for yourself.

title: The Moment Doesnâ€™t Take Charli XCX Seriously & Neither Should We
text:
The Moment Doesnâ€™t Take Charli XCX Seriously & Neither Should We

Mild spoilers ahead. Charli XCX hates being famous. Sheâ€™s also terrified of becoming irrelevant. She loves pop music but couldnâ€™t care less about being a pop star. She thinks the word â€œcuntâ€ is cool, but â€œbitchâ€ is cringe. Well, at least this is the Charli XCX we see in The Moment, a satirical mockumentary that takes aim at the music industry, standom, and how both treat the artists at their center. As a heightened version of herself in the Aidan Zamiri-directed film, Charli XCX is at once a decisive musician who knows exactly what her image should be, and a distressed pop pawn torn between label requests and capitalistic endeavors to turn her viral â€œbrat summerâ€ into a booming brand. The Moment, which premiered this weekend at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, finds Charli XCX at a crossroads; sheâ€™s ready to say goodbye to her seminal 2024 album Brat but anxious about what comes after your entire career has been whittled into a neon(ish) shade of green and an indescribable aesthetic. What happens when you become a punchline?Â 

The answer, according to Charli and the team behind A24â€™s The Moment, is to start making the jokes yourself. The Moment is at its best when it doesnâ€™t take itself seriously, when it leans into being a searing commentary on fame and stardom, and when it makes fun of Brat Summer, a concept that (aside from the music, which was very good) already feels like it was a fever dream/ recession indicator of a lost era, even though it was just about 20 months ago. Brat Summer existed in the â€œpost-pandemicâ€ rarified space of hopefulness America seemed to have before Trump was re-elected, when partying was back, and our feeds felt less dystopian. Lest we forget, a core tenet of the Brat era was that it was fun, and for the most part, The Moment is too. The film takes us back to 2024, right before Charli XCX is to tour the album, when the Brat phenomenon is on its last legs. The film is ruthless in its depiction of record execs, the business side of the music industry, and the commodification of artists â€” as it should be. As her image is being chopped, skewed, and sold for parts, Charli (a genuinely good actor) toggles between aloof disinterest and manic frustration. So how much of the real Charli XCX is in The Moment?Â 

â€œThe thing about Charli isâ€¦ sheâ€™s so authentically herself, and sheâ€™s not afraid to open up and show you all the moving parts inside of her,â€ Charliâ€™s co-star, Isaac Powell, said on the Sundance red carpet at the premiere of The Moment. â€œI felt like I got to know the real [Charli] and youâ€™ll see the real her in this movie. Sheâ€™s an open book. I donâ€™t think anyone will be surprised by anything.â€

The most surprising thing about The Moment isnâ€™t who Charli is â€” or isnâ€™t â€” pretending to be, but who she says sheâ€™s not. Charli XCX isnâ€™t the kind of pop star who likes pyrotechnics or stunts where sheâ€™s suspended in the air wearing sparkles and harnessed to an apparatus. Sound familiar? Charli XCX is probably never going to confirm or deny if the jabs at packaged pop princesses that are made in the film are direct hits on Taylor Swift (who allegedly dissed Charli on her most recent album), but it was surprising to me how unsubtle they were. Swift has produced many over-the-top concert films. When a trailer for Charli XCXâ€™s fake music film drops in The Moment, it looks like itâ€™s ripped from the Disney Plus discover page trying to redirect you to watch the Eras Tour. Itâ€™s very Swift-coded to say the least. But Swift isnâ€™t the only pop star to make a concert doc, and sheâ€™s not the only one who dons a sequinned mic and suspends in the air over her fans during her acts. Sheâ€™s not the only billionaire poster child for how pop music has become a marketing machine more concerned with bottom lines than quality music. It could just be a coincidence, right?Â  â€” or Charli XCX and Taylor Swift are engaged in a pop star petty-off. I, for one, am here for it. If Swift can (allegedly) throw shots at Charli XCX, why shouldnâ€™t she shoot back?Â 

The Moment star Tish Weinstock said the confusion over what is a performance and whatâ€™s not in the film is the point. â€œThe fact that itâ€™s all a performance is very telling,â€ Weinstock said at the premiere. â€œI think the tension lies in trying to find out the truth. Do you ever know anyone? Every day people are performing who they are, and this movie is a commentary on that.â€

Charliâ€™s performance of who she is in The Moment isnâ€™t always a flattering one. When she blows off her creative director (played excellently by Hailey Benton Gates, giving a nuanced, exasperated yet restrained performance that sometimes outshines its material) in the middle of tour rehearsals to go to a wellness spa in Ibiza, Charli XCX is being a brat â€” and not in the coked-out, absurdist chic way she intended. Charli is running from fame, and she runs into Kylie Jenner, naturally (Rachel Sennott and Julia Fox also deliver strong cameos). Itâ€™s a bit on the nose to include a Kardashian, the first family of being famous for fameâ€™s sake, but somehow it works. Jenner surprisingly holds her own while presumably also playing a heightened version of herself. Sheâ€™s passive aggressively pissed at Charli for stealing the in-demand director Kylie and her sister (she didnâ€™t specify which one) wanted for their own project. This causes Charli to spiral, and to call her team demanding they give the hotshot director, who has been tapped for Charliâ€™s concert film, anything he wants. The director, Johannes, is played by Alexander SkarsgÃ¤rd who is having the time of his life in this role.

Johannes acts as a stand-in for all the shitty men women in music have to deal with, the ones who condescend, belittle, mansplain, and gaslight. He does all that cloaked in therapy speak and bad clothes. SkarsgÃ¤rd is truly hilarious â€” albeit disturbing â€” in the role. Itâ€™s in the scenes with Johannes, the gaggle of other bros, and Rosanna Arquetteâ€™s clueless record executive, who each are attempting to sell, monopolize and destroy Charliâ€™s image, that the movie finds its footing. The movie is a ridiculous takedown of how silly this industry is, and how unserious Brat Summer was. When sheâ€™s at her most self-deprecating, The Momentâ€™s Charli XCX is extremely likeable, and the world sheâ€™s critiquing is all about extremes.Â 

â€œFame is sacrificing your privacy but also getting everything that you want,â€ Weinstock said when asked to describe fame and the filmâ€™s explanation of it. â€œDeal with it.â€Â 

As Charli XCX deals with it, sheâ€™s grappling with having it all while wanting none of it. The last act of the film could be interpreted as a sincere rumination on the mental toil of massive success, and the loss of creative freedom, but itâ€™s also where the movieâ€™s message gets muddled. It may seem hard to feel bad for someone who got everything she wanted, but the genuine emotions that Charli the actress delivers help you root for this anti-heroine, even when youâ€™re rooting for her multi-million dollar Brat credit card deal not to fall through. The viewer gets just as caught up in the allure of Chari XCX as the parasocial stans sheâ€™s referencing. But Charli XCX is taking the piss out of herself, her fans, and their co-dependency. She can leave the sincerity for the sparkly pop stars.Â 

Deadline called The Moment a â€œspiritual sequel to Spice Worldâ€ and Iâ€™ll go further and call it Spice World meets Uncut Gems. Complimentary! Ultimately, Charli XCXâ€™s fans will love her irreverent approach and newcomers will be endeared by her self awareness. Thereâ€™s a scene near the beginning of the film where Charli asks one of her team members if something related to Brat Summer was too cringe. They reply, â€œItâ€™s all cringe.â€ Making a meta anti-concert film to say goodbye to an era that had cable news debating whether the Vice President was â€œbratâ€ is a little cringe. The Momentâ€™s Charli XCX would lean into it. Sure, itâ€™s all cringe, but cringe sells, and thatâ€™s all that matters.Â 

The Moment is in theaters on January 30.Â
